summary: This document is an email chain from February 2019 discussing a meeting to review a potential sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email, forwarded on February 24, 2019, references a pitch made earlier that week by lawyers, including Pete Skinner, representing a victim who was 16 at the time of the alleged abuse. The email notes Epstein's history, his 2007 non-prosecution agreement, and the complexity of the case.

persons.name: Pete Skinner
persons.context: One of the lawyers who came in earlier in the week to pitch a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein, representing a victim.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the potential sex trafficking case. Described as a financier with multiple homes, alleged to have had dozens of victims, and who entered into a non-prosecution agreement in 2007.

connections.description: Skinner, as a lawyer, is pitching a case against Epstein on behalf of a victim, indicating an attorney-client relationship with the victim and an adversarial legal stance against Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Lawyer Pitch on Epstein Case
events.description: Earlier in the week of February 24, 2019, Pete Skinner and two other lawyers pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York.

keyFacts: In February 2019, lawyers including Pete Skinner pitched a new federal sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York.
The case involved a victim who was 16 years old at the time she was allegedly prostituted by Epstein.
The email notes Epstein 'apparently had dozens of victims' and that his criminal conduct may have been ongoing.
The 2007 non-prosecution agreement Epstein entered into with the Southern District of Florida is acknowledged as a complicating factor.
The document indicates internal deliberation within the U.S. Attorney's Office about pursuing the case, describing the facts as 'intriguing and complicated'.
